results.title: Suffering
results.description: Unpleasantness, discontentment, dissatisfaction, stress, pain, disease, i.e. mild or intense suffering that is inherent in conditioned existence.

results.title: Dukkha sutta - Suffering
results.description: Six qualities to dwell in ease, without distress, without anguish - 1) thoughts of relinquishment, 2) non-ill will, 3) non-harming, 4) perceptions of relinquishment, 5) non-ill will, 6) non-harming.

results.title: Dukkhavihāra sutta - Discontented Abiding
results.description: A person endowed with the two qualities of guarding the sense doors and moderation in eating lives with discontentedness in this very life and after death, a bad destination is expected.

results.title: Dukkhanibbānasappāya sutta - Discontentment As Suitable For Realizing Nibbāna
results.description: The way of practice suitable for realizing Nibbāna is to see the six sense bases and their objects as sources of discontentment.

results.title: Recognition of unsatisfactoriness
results.description: Perceiving the inherent inadequacy and unreliability of conditioned existence. This recognition loosens craving and the pursuit of lasting satisfaction in what cannot endure.

results.title: Dutiya sutta - Companion
results.description: A deity asks the Buddha what serves as a person‘s companion, what instructs him, and delighting in what is a mortal freed from all suffering.

results.title: Sukha sutta - Pleasant
results.description: Seeing the vanishing nature of the experience that arises with each contact—whether felt as pleasant, painful, or as neither-painful-nor-pleasant—one becomes dispassionate towards it.

results.title: Dutiya jana sutta - Gives Rise To (Second)
results.description: A deity asks the Buddha what gives rise to a person, what does he have that wanders about, what experiences cyclic existence, and from what is this person not yet freed.

results.title: Paṭhama saññā sutta - Perceptions (First)
results.description: Seven perceptions, of 1) unattractiveness, 2) death, 3) unpleasantness of food, 4) non-delight in the whole world, 5) impermanence, 6) unsatisfactoriness in impermanence, and 7) not-self in unsatisfac

results.title: Vipallāsa sutta - Inversion
results.description: The Buddha describes these four inversions of perception, thought, and view, and the four non-inversions. An uninstructed ordinary person perceives permanence in the impermanent, pleasure in the unsat

results.title: Sabbapariññā sutta - Completely Comprehending Everything
results.description: One is incapable of ending suffering without directly knowing and completely comprehending everything, without the mind detaching from it and without abandoning it. One is capable of ending suffering

results.title: Paṭhama sekha sutta - Trainee (First)
results.description: There is no other single factor as helpful as wise attention for a trainee bhikkhu who is aspiring for the highest goal.

results.title: Bhidura sutta - Fragile
results.description: The body is fragile, consciousness is of a fading nature. All substrates of existence are impermanent, unsatisfactory, and subject to change.

results.title: Kumāraka sutta - Boys
results.description: If suffering is displeasing to you, do not commit evil deeds, whether openly or in secret.

results.title: Dutiya lakuṇḍakabhaddiya sutta - Lakuṇḍaka Bhaddiya (Second)
results.description: Seeing venerable Sāriputta instructing venerable Lakuṇḍaka Bhaddiya even more, considering him to be a trainee despite his mind having already been liberated, the Blessed One expresses an inspired utt

results.title: Tatha sutta - Actual
results.description: The Four Noble Truths are actual, unchanging, and not otherwise; therefore, they are called the Noble Truths.

results.title: Ātappakaraṇīya sutta - Vigour
results.description: The Buddha describes three cases where vigour should be applied.

results.title: Paṭhama lokadhamma sutta - Worldly Conditions (First)
results.description: The Buddha describes in brief the eight worldly conditions that revolve around the world and the world revolves around them - gain and loss, disgrace and fame, blame and praise, pleasure, and pain.

results.title: Upādāna sutta - Clinging
results.description: The Buddha uses the simile of a bonfire to explain how perceiving gratification in objects that can be grasped at leads to clinging, to suffering, and how perceiving drawbacks in objects that can be g

results.title: Titthāyatana sutta - Bases Of Sectarian Views
results.description: The Buddha explains the three bases of sectarian views that when closely examined, culminate in inaction. He then shares the Dhamma that is irrefutable, undefiled, blameless, and not disapproved of by
